description: How can architecture help us to understand a world in flux? We can use buildings as markers of change, seeing the impact of global economic shifts on local streets, the rise and fall of public housing, and the march of 'gentrification'.

factsheet.heading: About the tour and guide
paragraphs: Starting in what was an ancient Roman burial ground in Spitalfields, we wind around the old Roman Route of Ermine Street. Looking up from the street, we use architecture to illustrate changes in local economies, housing, transport, and the impact of gentrification. We also look at symbolism and codes written in stone: if buildings could talk, what would they say?
Guide: Ian Kernohan has been a London resident for over 25 years and is a post-graduate student of architectural history, with an keen interest in social history and public housing.

factsheet.heading: Golden Key Academy
paragraphs: This tour is led by a participant of Open City’s Golden Key Academy – a course training up insightful and engaging guides dedicated to explaining London and bringing its many stories to life. It is part of a wider collection of tour events created by Golden Key Academy guides for the Open House Festival celebrating their conclusion of the six month course.

factsheet.heading: Tour meeting point:
paragraphs:
Meet by the 'I Goat' sculpture on Brushfield St
Brushfield Street (opposite Hotel Chocolate)
LONDON
E1 6AA

factsheet.heading: ALL GOLDEN KEY ACADEMY TOURS ARE STILL GOING AHEAD
paragraphs: THIS TOUR IS GOING AHEAD. PLEASE TURN UP OR CANCEL YOUR PLACE IF YOU CAN NO LONGER MAKE IT. (Info added 9/09/22)

name: Walking around Ermine Street, Spitalfields
